newsitem.title: australia: Australians not racists, says PM Howard.
newsitem.headline: Australians not racists, says PM Howard.

text.p: Prime Minister John Howard on Thursday defended Australia as a tolerant society, but once again refused to condemn a maverick politician whose remarks have driven a xenophobic national debate on immigration.
"I do not believe Australia is made up of a mob of bigots," Howard said in a lengthy Sydney radio interview dominated by the issue of race.

"Australians are to be congratulated, not denigrated, for the extraordinary tolerance and decency (they) have demonstrated over the years to successive waves of migration from different parts of the world," Howard said.
Howard said Australia had the second highest population growth in the developed world in the 1980s, fuelled almost entirely by immigration.

But the conservative prime minister refused to speak out decisively to end a debate on immigration and race, which has heightened racial tensions and seen one town mayor call children of mixed race marriages "mongrels".

The race debate was sparked last month when politician Pauline Hanson made a parliamentary speech claiming the country was being swamped by Asians and that indigenous Aborigines were gaining unfair preferential treatment.
Howard, who in 1988 questioned the level of Asian immigration to Australia, said an immigration debate was long overdue, but called for a sensitive and tolerant discussion.
"The immigration policy is meant to serve the interest of Australia and not to serve the interest of a particular ideology," he told Sydney commercial radio station 2UE.
Asked to condem independent politician Pauline Hanson, Howard said: "I am not going to have this debate hijacked by responding to the speech by an independent in parliament".
"We all have a responsibility to keep the damn thing in perspective...and also you don't want to turn people into martyrs...," Howard said.
"In the process of taking the cork out of the bottle, we've got to be certain that the ratbags and the bigots...get treated as they deserve...with contempt."
Australia introduced non-discriminatory immigration in the early 1970s after years of a "white Australia" policy and Howard said the government did not intend to turn back.
But he said he defended people's right to free speech.

"I will of course defend the right of any Australian to argue in a reasonable and sensitive fashion for any proposition. (But) there will always be some unreasonable and insensitive people. You will never get a perfect society."
Ethnic leaders on Thursday criticised Howard for failing to show leadership by not condeming Hanson and her comments.

"I think there needs to be an unequivocal, bi-partisan appeal for condemnation against racism and for multiculturalism and immigration and indigenous people in Australia," said Angela Chan, chair of the News South Ethnic Communities Council.
"What we've seen recently with Pauline Hanson and her like is not only a threat to our racial harmony but a blow to our political process," Chan said.

Recent newspaper polls have shown that more than seven out of 10 Australian voters believe immigration levels are too high, despite a government plan to cut them by 11 percent over the current financial year.
